text.p: PARIS, Jan 9 (Reuter) These are the leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.

-- State to take over some 134.2 billion francs, up nine billion francs from plans unveiled last June, of infrastructure-related debt from state-owned railroad operator SNCF, to help it return to financial balance. (Les Echos, La Tribune, Le Figaro, Liberation).
-- Economists reach consensus for 1997 GDP growth around 2 percent, a prerequisite for France to tackle public deficits and meet Maastricht treaty criteria and timetable. (Le Figaro).

-- National statistics office survey finds company cash flow in good shape thanks to lower interest rates and improving sales volume in most industries, but automobile sector remains fragile and investment prospects are scarce.
-- Prime Minister Alain Juppe vows to seek better communication between government and the French people.
-- Southern European countries angered by Dutch finance minister's talk of a reduced European monetary union for 1999, which may exclude Italy, Spain and Portugal.
-- Labour unions oppose labour flexibility called for by some to help reduce unemployment, criticise planned introduction of pension funds in France.
-- Planned branch office restructuring at the Bank of France may jeopardise up to 1,000 jobs.

-- Banks asked to audit value of Aerospatiale prior to merger with Dassault have diverging points of view -- Paribas estimates Aerospatiale to be worth some 4.5 billion francs, Lazard sees it as worth 25 to 28 billion. Privatisation commission to take final estimate.
-- Structure selling off Credit Lyonnais assets considers selling its share in Rhone-Poulenc, in which it holds a five percent stake.
-- France will privatise aerospace company after merger of Aerospatiale and Dassault planned for spring of 1997
-- Lazard chief Michel David-Weill says he has no immediate plans to step down, and has not yet appointed a successor.
